dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, 265 asylum seekers and 301 refugees currently in Kazakhstan, mostly in Almaty and the surrounding region.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, two hundred sixty five asylum seekers and three hundred one refugees currently in Kazakhstan, mostly in Almaty and the surrounding region.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the report, 265 asylum seekers and 301 refugees currently reside in Kazakhstan, with most of them living in Almaty and Almaty Region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's interesting that they've been a party to the UN Refugee Convention since, uh, December 15, 1998.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's interesting that they've been a party to the U N Refugee Convention since, uh, December fifteen, nineteen ninety eight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Ministry noted that on December 15, 1998, Kazakhstan officially acceded to the 1951 UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and assumed certain obligations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which means they're bound by those international principles—non-refoulement, non-discrimination, all of that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which means they're bound by those international principles-non-refoulement, non-discrimination, all of that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Public relations concerning the legal status of asylum seekers and refugees in Kazakhstan are governed by the Law ˜On Refugees,' based on principles of international refugee law: non-refoulement, transparency and accessibility in granting refugee status, non-discrimination, confidentiality, family unity, and protection of refugee children's rights, the Ministry reminded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the law here, the "On Refugees" law, really seems to codify those protections, like free medical care and social support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the law here, the On Refugees law, really seems to codify those protections, like free medical care and social support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Asylum seekers and refugees in Kazakhstan are entitled to free medical care and social support, as stipulated by law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, they don't need work permits, which is a huge deal for people trying to rebuild their lives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, they don't need work permits, which is a huge deal for people trying to rebuild their lives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike other foreigners, they do not need special work permits from local authorities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, they can just work or start businesses like anyone else. And their kids get full access to education, all the way up through university.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, they can just work or start businesses like anyone else. And their kids get full access to education, all the way up through university.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They are also free to work and run businesses. Refugee children have the same educational rights as other children in Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's such a critical point—education from kindergarten to postgraduate, on a competitive basis, no less.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's such a critical point-education from kindergarten to postgraduate, on a competitive basis, no less.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They can attend kindergartens and schools for free, and are eligible to apply for higher and postgraduate education on a competitive basis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's the path to permanent residence and even citizenship, without needing a criminal record certificate from back home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's the path to permanent residence and even citizenship, without needing a criminal record certificate from back home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Additionally, refugees can apply for permanent residence and citizenship in Kazakhstan. They are not required to submit a criminal record certificate from their home country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which, honestly, makes sense—if you're fleeing persecution, how are you supposed to get that paperwork?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, honestly, makes sense-if you're fleeing persecution, how are you supposed to get that paperwork?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And I remember last year they introduced new refugee ID cards that meet international machine-readable standards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And I remember last year they introduced new refugee I D cards that meet international machine-readable standards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a reminder, last year Kazakhstan approved a new format for refugee identification cards. It was noted that these IDs are produced in accordance with international standards for machine-readable travel documents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, that update is definitely a step toward better integration and recognition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, that update is definitely a step toward better integration and recognition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And just a few months ago, in November, they reported refugees from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And just a few months ago, in November, they reported refugees from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It's also worth noting that in November 2023, it was reported that 325 refugees from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Syria, and China were residing in Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Syria and China as well. It's a really diverse group seeking safety there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Syria and China as well. It's a really diverse group seeking safety there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It's also worth noting that in November 2023, it was reported that 325 refugees from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Syria, and China were residing in Kazakhstan.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like Kazakhstan's framework is actually pretty robust compared to some other places.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sounds like Kazakhstan's framework is actually pretty robust compared to some other places.
